messageBody:
--- In Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com, John Cowan <cowan@...> wrote:
>
> it's no more complicated than Arabic, after all.
>

I fear this is not the case: the complexity is more comparable to
Pitman or Gregg shorthand than Arabic. For one thing, the choice of
connection in one part of a word can affect the connections many
letters away. For another, there are three lines on which letters
connect and even then, the direction of connection is not always
merely across. And there are cases where a following letter is not to
the right of its predecessor but vertically displaced as are
subsequent connections. Also, even on the same line, some letters can
not connect to others based on their relative angle of approach to
that line: not every medial form can connect to every other medial form.

Even in those cases when QS does behave somewhat like Arabic, it is
significantly more complex. Misappropriating terminology from Arabic,
each letter not only has isolated, initial, medial and final forms but
for each initial form there are usually two variants and in some cases
(like Sea) there are three. For final forms there are again two
variants. For medial forms there are all permutations of the above.
And of course some letters have half forms each of which has several
of initial, medial and final. And of course there are step variations
to each half letter that have several of initial, medial and final.


>
> Of course, modern typography can manage SQS fine.
>

The current TrueType spec can not.
